title: Precalculus and Advanced Topics
teaser: Students explore transformations, vectors and matrices, rational and exponential functions, trigonometry, probability and statistics.

children.title: Complex Numbers and Transformations
children.teaser: Students study of complex numbers and linear transformations in the complex plane.

children.title: A Question of Linearity
children.teaser: Students begin the study of linearity.

children.title: Wishful Thinking-Does Linearity Hold?
children.teaser: Students develop familiarity with linearity conditions.

children.title: Wishful Thinking-Does Linearity Hold? (Continued)
children.teaser: Students develop familiarity with linearity conditions.

children.title: Which Real Number Define a Linear Transformation?
children.teaser: Students develop facility with the properties that characterize linear transformations.

children.title: An Appearance of Complex Numbers
children.teaser: Students solve quadratic equations with complex solutions.

children.title: An Appearance of Complex Numbers (Continued)
children.teaser: Students describe complex numbers and represent them as points in the complex plane.

children.title: Complex Numbers and Vectors
children.teaser: Students represent complex numbers as vectors.

children.title: Complex Number Division
children.teaser: Students determine the conjugate of a complex number.

children.title: Complex Number Division (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use the concept of conjugate to divide complex numbers.

children.title: Complex Number Operations and Transformations
children.teaser: Students develop an understanding of the geometric effect of operations on complex numbers.

children.title: The Geometric Effect of Some Complex Arithmetic
children.teaser: Students represent addition, subtraction, and conjugation of complex numbers.

children.title: The Geometric Effect of Some Complex Arithmetic (Continued)
children.teaser: Students interpret probabilities in context.

children.title: Distance and Complex Numbers
children.teaser: Students calculate distances between complex numbers as the modulus of the difference.

children.title: Distance and Complex Numbers (Continued)
children.teaser: Students apply distances between complex numbers and the midpoint of a segment.

children.title: Trigonometry and Complex Numbers
children.teaser: Students represent complex numbers in polar form and convert between rectangular and polar representations.

children.title: Discovering the Geometric effect of Complex Multiplication
children.teaser: Students determine the geometric effects of transformations.

children.title: Justifying the Geometric Effect of Complex Multiplication
children.teaser: Students understand effects of linear transformations.

children.title: Representing Reflections with Transformations
children.teaser: Students create a sequence of transformations.

children.title: The Geometric Effect of Multiplying by a Reciprocal
children.teaser: Students understand the geometric effects of multiple operations with complex numbers.

children.title: The Power of the Right Notation
children.teaser: Students explore various notations.

children.title: Exploiting the Connection to Trigonometry
children.teaser: Students calculate powers of a complex number.

children.title: Exploiting the Connection to Trigonometry (Continued)
children.teaser: Students calculate the roots of a complex number.

children.title: Exploiting the Connection to Cartesian Coordinates
children.teaser: Students interpret complex multiplication as the corresponding function of two real variables.

children.title: The Hunt for Better Notation
children.teaser: Students multiply matrix products.

children.title: Modeling Video Game Motion with Matrices
children.teaser: Students use matrix transformations to represent motion along a straight line.

children.title: Modeling Video Game Motion with Matrices (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use matrix transformations to model circular motion.

children.title: Matrix Notation Encompasses New Transformations!
children.teaser: Students understand the role of the multiplicative identity matrix.

children.title: Matrix Multiplication and Addition
children.teaser: Students understand the role of the zero matrix in matrix addition.

children.title: Getting a Handle on New Transformations
children.teaser: Students calculate the area of thetransformed figure.

children.title: Getting a Handle on New Transformations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand that 2 × 2 matrix transformations are linear transformations.

children.title: When Can We Reverse a Transformation?
children.teaser: Students determine inverse matrices using linear systems.

children.title: When Can We Reverse a Transformation? (Continued...)
children.teaser: Students explore inverse transformations.

children.title: When Can We Reverse a Transformation? (Continued)
children.teaser: Students explore if transformations can be reversed.

children.title: Vectors and Matrices
children.teaser: Students look at relationships in networks and encode information about them.

children.title: Networks and Matrices
children.teaser: Students are introduced to networks.

children.title: Introduction to Networks
children.teaser: Students use matrices to model new phenomena, starting with networks and graphs.

children.title: Networks and Matrix Arithmetic
children.teaser: Students use matrices to represent data.

children.title: Matrix Arithmetic in its Own Right
children.teaser: Students use matrices to represent data based on transportation networks.

children.title: Linear Transformations of Planes and Space
children.teaser: Students explore the geometric context for higher-dimensional matrices.

children.title: Linear Transformations Review
children.teaser: Students form conjectures about linear transformations in three-dimensional space.

children.title: Coordinates of Points in Space
children.teaser: Students use parallelograms to interpret the sum of two points in ℝ geometrically.

children.title: Linear Transformations as Matrices
children.teaser: Students verify that 3 x 3 matrices represent linear transformations.

children.title: Linear Transformations Applied to Cubes
children.teaser: Students construct matrices so that the linear transformation has a desired geometric effect.

children.title: Composition of Linear Transformations
children.teaser: Students examine the geometric effects of performing a sequence of two linear transformations.

children.title: Composition of Linear Transformations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use technology to perform compositions of linear transformations.

children.title: Matrix Multiplication Is Not Commutative
children.teaser: Students understand that matrix multiplication is not commutative.

children.title: Matrix Addition Is Commutative
children.teaser: Students prove that matrix addition is commutative.

children.title: Matrix Multiplication Is Distributive and Associative
children.teaser: Students discover and verify that matrix-multiplication is both distributive and associative.

children.title: Using Matrix Operations for Encryption
children.teaser: Students study and practice the properties of matrix multiplication.

children.title: Systems of Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students revisit matrices via the study of systems of linear equations.

children.title: Solving Equations Involving Linear Transformations of the Coordinate Plane
children.teaser: Students represent systems of equations as linear-transformations.

children.title: Solving Equations Involving Linear Transformations of the Coordinate Space
children.teaser: Students apply inverse matrix operations to solve systems of linear equations.

children.title: Solving General Systems of Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students use technology to calculate the inverse of matrices.

children.title: Vectors in Plane and Space
children.teaser: Students explore vector magnitude along with the geometrical frameworks for these operations.

children.title: Vectors in the Coordinate Plane
children.teaser: Students add and subtract vectors.

children.title: Vectors and Translation Maps
children.teaser: Students use vectors to define a translation-map and translate geometric figures.

children.title: Directed Line Segments and Vectors
children.teaser: They understand vector arithmetic from a geometric perspective.

children.title: Vectors and Stone Bridges
children.teaser: Students understand the forces involved in constructing a stone arch.

children.title: Vectors and the Equation of a Line
children.teaser: Students convert between parametric equations and the slope-intercept form of a line.

children.title: Linear Transformations of Lines
children.teaser: Students write parametric equations for a line through two points.

children.title: Why Are Vectors Useful?
children.teaser: Students solve problems involving physical phenomena that can be represented by vectors.

children.title: Why Are Vectors Useful? (Continued)
children.teaser: Students apply linear transformations and vectors.

children.title: First-Person Video Games—Projection Matrices
children.teaser: Students understand how first-person video games use matrix operations.

children.title: First-Person Computer Games
children.teaser: Students understand that vanishing points can be used to project three-dimensional objects onto two-dimensional space.

children.title: Projecting a 3-D Object onto a 2-D Plane
children.teaser: Students learn to project points in 3-dimensional space onto a 2-dimensional plane.

children.title: Designing Your Own Game
children.teaser: Students create a short animation in ALICE 3.1 using one-step procedures.

children.title: Rational and Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students explore complex roots of polynomial functions.

children.title: Polynomial Functions and the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
children.teaser: Students extend familiar polynomial identities complex numbers and polynomial functions.

children.title: Solutions to Polynomial Equations
children.teaser: Students determine all solutions of polynomial equations over the set of complex numbers.

children.title: Does Every Complex Number Have a Square Root?
children.teaser: Students apply their understanding of polynomial identities to complex numbers.

children.title: Roots of Unity
children.teaser: Students determine the complex roots of polynomial equations.

children.title: The Binomial Theorem
children.teaser: Students discover patterns in the expansion of binomials.

children.title: The Binomial Theorem (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use the binomial theorem to solve problems in a geometric context.

children.title: Curves in the Complex Plane
children.teaser: Students write equations of ellipses and represent them graphically.

children.title: Curves from Geometry
children.teaser: Students derive the equations of ellipses given the foci.

children.title: Curves from Geometry (Continued)
children.teaser: Students establish connection between ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

children.title: Volume and Cavalieri’s Principle
children.teaser: Students give an informal argument using Cavalieri’s principle.

children.title: Rational Functions and Composition of Functions
children.teaser: Students explore composition of functions in depth.

children.title: The Structure of Rational Expressions
children.teaser: Students add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.

children.title: Rational Functions
children.teaser: Students reduce rational expressions to lowest terms.

children.title: End Behavior of Rational Functions
children.teaser: Students describe the end behavior of rational functions.

children.title: Horizontal and Vertical Asymptotes of Graphs of Rational Functions
children.teaser: Students develop understanding of the key features of rational functions.

children.title: Graphing Rational Functions
children.teaser: Students graph rational functions showing intercepts, asymptotes, and end behavior.

children.title: Transforming Rational Functions
children.teaser: Students graph transformations of rational functions.

children.title: Function Composition
children.teaser: Students compose functions and describe the domain and range of the compositions.

children.title: Solving Problems by Function Composition
children.teaser: Students solve problems by composing functions.

children.title: Precalculus: Inverse Functions
children.teaser: Students understand when inverse functions do and do not exist.

children.title: Inverse Functions
children.teaser: Students read the inverse values of a function from a table and graph.

children.title: Restricting the Domain
children.teaser: Students choose a suitable domain to create an invertible function.

children.title: Inverses of Logarithmic and Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students compose functions to verify that exponential functions and logarithmic functions are inverses.

children.title: Logarithmic and Exponential Problem Solving
children.teaser: Students understand the inverse-relationship between logarithms and exponents applying their understanding to solve real-world problems.

children.title: Trigonometry
children.teaser: Students solve geometric and modeling problems through trigonometry.

children.title: Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students develop and justify conjectures about the behavior of trigonometric functions.

children.title: Special Triangles and the Unit Circle
children.teaser: Students use the unit-circle to express the values of the sine, cosine, and tangent functions.

children.title: Properties of Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students explore the symmetry and periodicity of trigonometric functions.

children.title: Addition and Subtraction Formulas
children.teaser: Students use the addition and subtraction formulas to evaluate trigonometric functions to solve problems.

children.title: Addition and Subtraction Formulas (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use the addition formulas to derive the double-angle formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent.

children.title: Tangent Lines and the Tangent Function
children.teaser: Students construct a tangent line.

children.title: Waves, Sinusoids, and Identities
children.teaser: Students use trigonometric identities to rewrite expressions and understand wave interference and standing waves.

children.title: Trigonometry and Triangles
children.teaser: Students derive sophisticated applications of the trigonometric functions.

children.title: An Area Formula for Triangles
children.teaser: Students reason geometrically and numerically to find the areas of various triangles.

children.title: Law of Sines
children.teaser: Students prove the law of sines and use it to solve problems.

children.title: Law of Cosines
children.teaser: Students prove the law of cosines and use it to solve problems.

children.title: Putting Law of Cosines and Law of Sines to Use
children.teaser: Students apply the law of sines or the law of cosines to determine missing measurements

children.title: Precalculus: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students explore how changing various parameters of a trigonometric function affects its graph.

children.title: Revisiting the Graphs of the Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students graph the sine, cosine, and tangent functions and analyze characteristics of their graphs.

children.title: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations.

children.title: Modeling with Inverse Trigonometric Functions
children.teaser: Students use inverse trigonometric functions to solve real-world problems addressing best viewing angles.

children.title: Modeling with Inverse Trigonometric Functions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students apply inverse trigonometric functions to solve problems in modeling contexts.

children.title: Probability and Statistics
children.teaser: Students build on their understanding of probability.

children.title: Probability
children.teaser: Students extend their understanding of probability.

children.title: The General Multiplication Rule
children.teaser: Students calculate the probability of the intersection of two events.

children.title: Counting Rules—The Fundamental Counting Principle and Permutations
children.teaser: Students calculate the number of different permutations of a set of distinct items.

children.title: Counting Rules—Combinations
children.teaser: Students calculate the number of different combinations of items selected from a set of items.

children.title: Using Permutations and Combinations to Compute Probabilities
children.teaser: Students distinguish between situations involving combinations and permutations.

children.title: Random Variables and Discrete Probability Distributions
children.teaser: Students distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables and focus on probability distributions.

children.title: Discrete Random Variables
children.teaser: Students understand discrete random variables.

children.title: Probability Distribution of a Discrete Random Variable
children.teaser: Students construct a graph of the probability distribution.

children.title: Expected Value of a Discrete Random Variable
children.teaser: Students calculate the expected value of a discrete random variable.

children.title: Interpreting Expected Value
children.teaser: Students interpret expected value in context.

children.title: Determining Discrete Probability Distributions
children.teaser: Students determine the probability distribution of that variable.

children.title: Determining Discrete Probability Distributions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students determine the probability distribution of a variable.

children.title: Estimating Probability Distributions Empirically
children.teaser: Students estimating probability distributions of discrete random variables.

children.title: Estimating Probability Distribution Empirically (Continued)
children.teaser: Students collect empirical data associated with a discrete random variable by simulation.

children.title: Using Probability to Make Decisions
children.teaser: Students analyze strategies and make decisions in a variety of contexts.

children.title: Games of Chance and Expected Value
children.teaser: Students analyze simple games of chance.

children.title: Game of Chance and Expected Value
children.teaser: Students use expected pay off to compare strategies for a simple game of chance.

children.title: Using Expected Values to Compare Strategies
children.teaser: Students calculate expected values.

children.title: Making Fair Decisions
children.teaser: Students use probabilities to make fair decisions.

children.title: Fair Games
children.teaser: Students use probability to learn what it means for a game to be fair.

children.title: Analyzing Decisions and Strategies Using Probability
children.teaser: Students compare strategies by evaluating their probabilities of success.

children.title: Analyzing Decisions and Strategies Using Probability (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use probability concepts to make decisions in a variety of contexts.
